sn55.42:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.
sn55.42:4.3: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.42:6.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
sn55.42:6.2: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.
sn55.42:6.3: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.
sn55.42:7.1: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
sn55.42:7.2: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.
sn55.42:7.3: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.
sn55.42:8.1: There are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—come together and converge.
sn55.42:8.2: It’s not easy measure how much water is in such places by saying
sn55.42:8.3: how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.
sn55.42:8.4: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.
sn55.42:8.5: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
sn55.42:8.6: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.
sn55.42:8.7: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”
sn55.42:8.8: This is what the Buddha said.
sn55.42:8.9: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn55.42:9.2: and though the rivers are many,
sn55.42:9.3: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,
sn55.42:9.4: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.
sn55.42:10.1: So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;
sn55.42:10.2: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—
sn55.42:10.3: the streams of merit reach that astute person,
sn55.42:10.4: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”
